meta.trail_reservation_note: All PR trails require mandatory online reservation via SIMplifica (simplifica.madeira.gov.pt) as of Jan 1, 2026. EUR 4.50/person/trail (PR1: EUR 10.50). 30-minute entry windows. Fine EUR 50-250 for hiking without valid reservation. Multi-day passes: 1-day EUR 9, 3-day EUR 22.50, 7-day EUR 52.50 (PR1 excluded). Residents free. Children under 12 free but must be registered.

items.name: PR1 - Vereda do Areeiro
items.tip: Madeira's #1 hike: Pico do Arieiro to Pico Ruivo. Currently closed (reopening Apr 2026). First 1.2km to Stairway to Heaven still accessible.
items.image_credit: Photo by Krzysztof Popławski, CC BY 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR1.2 - Vereda do Pico Ruivo
items.tip: Only way to summit Pico Ruivo (1862m) while PR1 is closed. Well-maintained stone path. Arrive early, parking fills by 9:30am.
items.image_credit: Photo by The Kopf System, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6 - Levada das 25 Fontes
items.tip: Iconic levada to 25-spring waterfall pool. 800m pitch-black tunnel. Shuttle from ER105 car park (EUR 3 down, EUR 2 up). Combine with PR6.1.
items.image_credit: Photo by muffinn from Worcester, UK, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.1 - Levada do Risco
items.tip: Easiest trail: flat walk to Madeira's tallest waterfall (100m). Perfect add-on to PR6 from same Rabacal trailhead.
items.image_credit: Photo by GerritR, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR8 - Vereda da Ponta de Sao Lourenco
items.tip: Highest-rated trail on AllTrails. Volcanic lunar landscape, no shade. Very windy. Bring 2L+ water. Cafe at Casa do Sardinha mid-trail.
items.image_credit: Photo by Diego Delso, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR9 - Levada do Caldeirao Verde
items.tip: 17.4km round trip to Green Cauldron waterfall. 4 tunnels with ankle-deep water. Full-day commitment. Spare socks essential.
items.image_credit: Photo by Günter Seggebäing, Coesfeld, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR10 - Levada do Furado
items.tip: 11km forest levada from Ribeiro Frio to Portela. Currently closed due to landslide. One of few trails accessible by public bus (Bus 56).
items.image_credit: Photo by Sergey Ashmarin, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR11 - Vereda dos Balcoes
items.tip: Shortest trail: flat 1.5km walk to iconic mountain viewpoint. Endemic Madeiran chaffinches feed from hands. Best effort-to-reward ratio.
items.image_credit: Photo by H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR13 - Vereda do Fanal
items.tip: Remote trail to 600-year-old twisted trees. Best in FOG. Most visitors drive directly to Fanal instead of full 10.8km hike.
items.image_credit: Photo by Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR17 - Caminho do Pinaculo e Folhadal
items.tip: Adventure hiker's trail. Two mega tunnels (500m + 1km) with ankle-deep water. Hardest tunnels on any Madeira trail. Partially open.
items.image_credit: Photo by Gerda Arendt, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR18 - Levada do Rei
items.tip: Peaceful, easy levada to pristine Ribeiro Bonito stream. Low crowds. Hidden gem among experienced hikers. Combine with Santana visit.
items.image_credit: Photo by Gerda Arendt, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Cabo Girao Skywalk
items.tip: 580m glass-bottom platform over Europe's highest sea cliff. Go early morning or after 4pm to avoid tour bus crowds.
items.image_credit: Photo by Dirk Klaassen, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Eira do Serrado
items.tip: Free viewpoint at 1095m. Iconic crater-like view over Valley of the Nuns. 25 min from Funchal. Check visibility first -- fog can completely obscure the valley. Footpath to village below (1h10m down).
items.image_credit: Photo by Ximonic (Simo Räsänen), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Pico do Arieiro
items.tip: 1818m, 3rd highest peak. SUNRISE above clouds is legendary. Near-freezing at dawn. Drive right up. PR1 start.

items.name: Miradouro dos Balcoes
items.tip: Best effort-to-reward viewpoint on the island. Easy 30min walk from Ribeiro Frio. Central peaks panorama. Endemic firecrests.
items.image_credit: Photo by Ramessos, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro da Portela
items.tip: Dramatic view of Penha d'Aguia rock and Porto da Cruz. Mystical when clouds pass through. Only 4 parking spaces.
items.image_credit: Luis Miguel Bugallo Sanchez, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro do Veu da Noiva
items.tip: Iconic Bridal Veil waterfall cascading from cliff into the sea. Quick photo stop en route to Porto Moniz. Best after rain.
items.image_credit: Photo by Diego Delso, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro das Cabanas
items.tip: One of the best sunset viewpoints on the island. Northwest coast panorama over Arco de Sao Jorge.

items.name: Miradouro do Guindaste
items.tip: Sea-level glass walkways 26m over the ocean. Unique low-angle perspective with Penha d'Aguia rock. Free.
items.image_credit: RHaworth, CC BY 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro da Ribeira da Janela
items.tip: Views over rock formations with 'window' hole rising from the ocean. Facilities, parking, playground. Combine with sea-level visit.
items.image_credit: Photo by Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Ponta do Rosto
items.tip: Volcanic dragon tail peninsula. Both north and south coasts visible. Colorful volcanic cliffs. Feels like another planet. PR8 start.
items.image_credit: Photo by Luis Miguel Bugallo Sánchez (Lmbuga), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro da Encumeada
items.tip: Two-sided views: north to Sao Vicente, south to Serra de Agua. Rare cloud waterfall phenomenon. Often fogged by midday.
items.image_credit: Gerda Arendt, CC0, Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro do Paredao
items.tip: Higher angle on Nun's Valley than Eira do Serrado. Less known, fewer crowds.
items.image_credit: VillageHero, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro do Cortado
items.tip: Dramatic cliff angles of Penha d'Aguia (590m), Faial promontory, and Ponta de Sao Lourenco in distance.

items.name: Miradouro da Torre
items.tip: Charming view of Camara de Lobos fishing village with colorful boats. Churchill painted this view.

items.name: Miradouro de Sao Cristovao Boaventura
items.tip: Impressive cliff formation meeting the sea from unusually low vantage point. Unique perspective.
items.image_credit: Gerda Arendt, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Miradouro Francisco Alvares Nobrega
items.tip: Best town views on Madeira: Machico valley, golden sand beach, marina, peninsula.

items.name: Miradouro da Faja da Ovelha
items.tip: Remote west coast feel. Paul do Mar village far below with plantations, cliffs, green terraces.

items.name: Rocha do Navio
items.tip: Cliffs, green farms, waterfalls plunging into ocean. Cable car currently closed. Spectacular even without descending.
items.image_credit: Thomas Hobbs, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Pico Ruivo do Paul
items.tip: 1640m peak. Paul da Serra plateau and Sao Vicente valley panorama. Quieter than Pico do Arieiro.

items.name: Bica da Cana
items.tip: 1560m. Alternative sunrise spot on Paul da Serra. Panoramic views to Arieiro and Ruivo. Empty parking.

items.name: Miradouro de Terra Grande
items.tip: 180-degree view of valleys and terraced plantations on south coast near Ribeira Brava. Easy roadside stop.

items.name: Miradouro do Fio
items.tip: Southwest tip cliffs, pebble beaches, sea. Tea house nearby.

items.name: Miradouro da Santinha
items.tip: Porto Moniz from above, vineyards, island panorama. Mountain road above town.

items.name: Miradouro do Cabouco
items.tip: Valley views with summits on road to Pico do Arieiro. Off beaten path.

items.name: Paul do Mar Viewpoint
items.tip: Isolated village at cliff base, sea and waves. Quiet, away from crowds.

items.name: Raposeira
items.tip: Paul do Mar from above. 10-min dirt trail from parking.

items.name: Miradouro Ponta da Ladeira
items.tip: Coast view and Faja da Quebrada Nova. Near Achadas da Cruz cable car.

items.name: Lombo do Mouro
items.tip: Sao Vicente valley and Pico Arieiro views along ER 110 mountain road.

items.name: Miradouro de Boa Morte
items.tip: Near Ponta do Pargo lighthouse. 180-degree ocean sunsets. 5-min descent walk.

items.name: Ponta do Tristao
items.tip: Northernmost point of Madeira. Off-beaten-path sunset. 5-min dirt path.

items.name: Pinaculo
items.tip: Best vantage point of Funchal city. Sunset location. Accessible by public bus.

items.name: Ponta do Sol Harbor Viewpoint
items.tip: Harbor and sunset views with beach restaurants. Warm microclimate.

items.name: Fanal
items.tip: Ancient Laurissilva forest with 600-year-old twisted trees. Atmospheric in fog, not a panoramic viewpoint.

items.name: Cristo Rei Garajau
items.tip: Christ statue viewpoint with ocean panorama.

items.name: Ponta do Pargo Lighthouse
items.tip: Westernmost point of Madeira. Sweeping 180-degree sunset views. Garganta Funda waterfall nearby.
items.image_credit: Photo by Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Porto Moniz Natural Pools (Paid)
items.tip: Classic Madeira swim. EUR 3. Lifeguards, changing rooms, children's pool. 3800m2 volcanic lava pools. Can close in storms.
items.image_credit: Photo by Xosema, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Porto Moniz Cachalote Pools (Free)
items.tip: Free rugged volcanic pools near the Aquarium. No lifeguard, no changing rooms. More authentic, confident swimmers only.

items.name: Seixal Natural Pools
items.tip: FREE volcanic pools with stunning lava arch. Arguably more beautiful than Porto Moniz. No lifeguards. Steep 33% access road.
items.image_credit: Photo by VinceTraveller, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Doca do Cavacas
items.tip: EUR 6 managed volcanic pools between Lido and Praia Formosa. Snorkeling, restaurant, south coast = calmer. Crystal clear.
items.image_credit: Photo by H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Calheta Golden Sand Beach
items.tip: Best traditional beach on Madeira. Imported golden sand from Morocco. Calm sheltered water, family-friendly. Free. Warm microclimate.
items.image_credit: Don Amaro, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Machico Golden Sand Beach
items.tip: Imported golden sand in sheltered bay. Full facilities, water sports. Good for arrival/departure day near airport. Free.
items.image_credit: Donarreiskoffer, CC BY 3.0, Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Seixal Black Sand Beach
items.tip: Natural black volcanic sand against green cliffs. 'Jamaica Beach' on Instagram. Photography 10/10, swimming risky in March.

items.name: Praia Formosa
items.tip: Largest public beach (2km). Pebble/dark sand. Blue Flag. Promenade to Camara de Lobos. 10 min from Funchal centre. Free.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Prainha
items.tip: Madeira's ONLY natural sandy beach. Volcanic black sand in sheltered cove. Calm, clear water. Unique arid landscape. Free.
items.image_credit: Photo by Michael Gaylard, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Porto da Cruz Beach
items.tip: Black pebble beach with best surf on Madeira. Penha d'Aguia backdrop. Not ideal for calm swimming. Wetsuits essential.

items.name: Faja dos Padres
items.tip: Secluded pebble beach below 300m cliff. Cable car EUR 10-12 or boat from Camara de Lobos. Pristine turquoise water, restaurant.
items.image_credit: Photo by Asurnipal, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Poco dos Chefes
items.tip: Natural freshwater swimming hole in Valley of the Nuns. Free. Too cold for March. Popular with locals in summer.

items.name: Praia dos Anjos
items.tip: Small pebble beach used by locals. Quiet, authentic, no tourists. Minimal facilities.

items.name: Monte Palace Tropical Garden
items.tip: Madeira's #1 garden. EUR 18. Koi ponds, azulejo tiles, museum, wine tasting included. Cable car closed until Apr 5 2026 -- take bus 20/21/22/48 (EUR 2-3) or taxi (EUR 13-16). Allow 2-3 hours.
items.image_credit: Photo by H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Jardim Botanico da Madeira
items.tip: EUR 6 -- best value garden on the island. 80,000m2, 2,500+ plants, 300 bird species (parrots, macaws). Natural History Museum included. Has its OWN cable car to Monte. Panoramic Funchal views.

items.name: Palheiro Gardens
items.tip: EUR 11. CAMELLIAS IN PEAK BLOOM IN MARCH. English estate feel blended with subtropical plants. Best garden for March visit.
items.image_credit: Photo by Hedwig Storch, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Jardim do Mar
items.tip: Not a formal garden -- car-free village nicknamed 'Garden of the Sea.' Subtropical flowers, narrow streets, surf spot. Free.

items.name: Quinta da Boa Vista
items.tip: Best orchid collection on the island. EUR 5. Weekdays only (closed weekends). Small but exquisite. 1 hour visit.

items.name: Santa Catarina Park
items.tip: Free public park. 36,000m2. Flower beds, Funchal and marina views, playground, cafe. Pleasant stroll, not destination-worthy alone.

items.name: Il Gallo d'Oro
items.tip: Only 2 Michelin stars on Madeira. EUR 245-295 tasting menus. Reserve well in advance. Dress code enforced.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Desarma
items.tip: 1 Michelin star. 11th-floor panoramic views over Funchal. Creative concept dining with tasting menus EUR 175-275.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: William Restaurant
items.tip: 1 Michelin star at Reid's Palace. EUR 105-160. Pair with afternoon tea at Reid's (EUR 30pp). Romantic Atlantic views.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Joy Restaurant
items.tip: Newest fine dining entrant, next to Savoy Palace. Contemporary tasting menus. Stylish modern design. Opened late 2024.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Avista
items.tip: Bib Gourmand. Same chef as Il Gallo d'Oro at fraction of price. EUR 25-70. Ocean terrace. Children's menu available.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Casal da Penha
items.tip: Bib Gourmand. Cobbled lanes. Black scabbardfish filet, lamb chops. Wine cellar upstairs. EUR 20-60.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Armazem do Sal
items.tip: Former medieval salt warehouse. Stone walls, wooden beams. Michelin-recommended. Shrimp risotto, soft-shell crab. EUR 25-80.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Tipografia
items.tip: Castanheiro Boutique Hotel. Revisited espada com banana with banana puree. Portuguese-Italian fusion. EUR 20-60.
items.image_credit: Espada preta, Carlos Teixidor Cadenas, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: 5 Sentidos
items.tip: Open kitchen. Small fresh menu that changes frequently. EUR 10 weekday lunch menu. Save for your last night.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Parrotfish, chocolate tart with salted caramel

items.name: Kampo
items.tip: Open kitchen by Chef Julio Pereira. Contemporary seasonal menu. Perfect for special occasions. Inventive without pretension.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: White chocolate, olive, and passion fruit dessert

items.name: AKUA
items.tip: Fresh fish and shellfish from display window. Black shrimp, prawns, mussels, lobsters. Old Town alley. EUR 30-50.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: La ao Fundo
items.tip: Madeiran staples with African and Indian twists. High-quality tuna and swordfish. Rustic stone walls, cosy atmosphere.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Goya
items.tip: Classical fine dining in hotel area/Lido. Exceptional passion fruit souffle. Prime choice for dates and celebrations.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Santa Maria Restaurant
items.tip: Old Town street-side terrace. Black pork cheek with truffle puree. Portuguese + sushi fusion. EUR 10-40.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Black pork cheek with truffle puree

items.name: Taberna Madeira
items.tip: Zona Velha. Grilled limpets, milho frito, sweet potato bread couvert. Tapas-style. Reliable first-night dinner.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Peixaria no Mercado
items.tip: Outdoor terrace overlooking market street. Cod croquettes with homemade tartar. Daily catch from market. EUR 20-40.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Cod croquettes with homemade tartar sauce

items.name: Zarcos
items.tip: Always packed with locals. Enormous portions. Steaks, fish, milho frito, passion fruit mousse. Arrive hungry.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Rustikus
items.tip: EUR 9.90 daily lunch specials. Locals queue out the door. Menu changes daily. No-frills quality. Arrive early.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: A Tendinha
items.tip: Cash only. Daily whiteboard menu. Fresh, no-frills, truly Madeiran. Unbeatable value.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Snack Bar Bela 5
items.tip: Family-run Funchal institution. Quality homemade food. End-of-day discounts on unused food. Rock-bottom prices.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: O Londres
items.tip: Canteen-like buzz with regulars. Tuna steaks, bacalhau a Bras, espetada. Daily pratos do dia. Skip the salmon.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante Dos Combatentes
items.tip: One of Funchal's oldest restaurants. Consistently good homemade food. Central location. Vegetarian options.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Ja Fui Jaquet
items.tip: On touristy Rua de Santa Maria but genuinely good value. EUR 12 four-course lunch. Fish pasta sharing pot at dinner.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: O Americano
items.tip: Tapas format for sampling multiple Madeiran dishes. House tuna with sweet potatoes and onions. EUR 10-30.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Barra Azul
items.tip: Right on Praia Formosa beach. Limpets, beef picados, octopus, espada with banana. Outdoor wooden seating.
items.image_credit: Espada preta, Carlos Teixidor Cadenas, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: A Bica
items.tip: Simple, traditional. The go-to for espada com banana and tuna steaks. Quality and freshness above all.
items.image_credit: Espada preta, Carlos Teixidor Cadenas, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Doca do Cavacas Restaurant
items.tip: By volcanic rock pools with Cabo Girao views. Red snapper highly recommended. Hidden gem location. EUR mid-range.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Informal
items.tip: Modern Portuguese with East Asian influence. Ramen, yakisoba, tempura. Two daily vegetarian/vegan options.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Sete Mares
items.tip: Two locations (Funchal port + Camara de Lobos). Nautical theme, harbor views. Tomato onion soup with poached egg.
items.image_credit: Câmara de Lobos, H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Tomato onion soup with poached egg, prego no bolo do caco

items.name: Restaurante Santo Antonio
items.tip: THE most famous espetada restaurant since 1966. Beef on bay laurel sticks. Family-run. Drive up through mountains is part of experience.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Espetada on laurel skewers, grilled chicken with milho frito

items.name: As Vides
items.tip: The FIRST restaurant to commercialize espetada (~1950). Traditional recipe with fried corn and potatoes. Budget-friendly.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: O Polar
items.tip: Beloved local institution in Camara de Lobos. Espetada, grilled chicken, homemade passion fruit pudding. Reservations recommended.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Espetada a Madeirense, passion fruit pudding

items.name: Vila da Carne
items.tip: Modern-yet-traditional in Camara de Lobos. Superior meat quality espetada. Traditional Madeiran recipe.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: O Lagar
items.tip: Former wine cellar in Camara de Lobos, family-run since 1995. Miniature Santana house at entrance. Fresh local produce.
items.image_credit: Câmara de Lobos, H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Vila do Peixe
items.tip: Pick-your-fish concept in Camara de Lobos. Floor-to-ceiling bay views. Select from live counter. Reserve ahead on weekends.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Day's catch -- tuna, sea bream, scabbardfish, grilled with salt

items.name: O Viola
items.tip: Warm and sophisticated near Camara de Lobos. Premium dry-aged meats. Ideal for special occasions.
items.image_credit: Câmara de Lobos, H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante Orca
items.tip: Terrace with ocean views next to natural pools. Tuna steak, spicy prawns, grilled limpets, prego no bolo do caco.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Bife de atum, gambas a diablo

items.name: Restaurante Polo Norte
items.tip: Inland Porto Moniz. Home-style cooking. Beef espetada, Portuguese wines. Friendly team. Ocean view terrace upstairs.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Sea View Restaurante
items.tip: Hidden gem near natural pools. Fish soup, grilled tuna with unique vegetable sides.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Conchinha Bar
items.tip: Quieter lunchtime alternative in Porto Moniz center. Sandwiches, salads, soups, maracuja cheesecake.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Zona Velha do Funchal, CC BY-SA 4.0 via Wikimedia

items.name: Restaurante Quinta do Furao
items.tip: Cliff-edge hotel restaurant. Oxtail tureen, slow-cooked beef cheek, mushroom risotto. Sea view. Summer terrace + winter fireplace.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Espetada, CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia

items.name: Cantinho da Serra
items.tip: Large fireplace, ideal for cooler days. Madeiran stew, carne de vinha d'alhos. Exclusively local products.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Lapas grelhadas, CC BY-SA 2.5 via Wikimedia
items.must_order: Madeiran stew, carne de vinha d'alhos

items.name: Marcel's Bistro
items.tip: Relaxing vibe in Santana. Prawns, bacalhau, cocktails. Avoid O Colmo, Estrela do Norte at lunch (coach tour crowds).
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Zona Velha do Funchal, CC BY-SA 4.0 via Wikimedia

items.name: Quebramar
items.tip: Rotating upper floor with sea views in Sao Vicente. Non-rotating tables downstairs. Traditional pilgrimage soup.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Espetada, CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia

items.name: Taberna de Sao Vicente
items.tip: Traditional Portuguese taberna atmosphere in Sao Vicente center. Bacalhau, bife espetada, milho fritas.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante Lavrador
items.tip: Cook-your-own beef/tuna on hot stone. Homemade bolo de mel. Family-run, mountain views. Book ahead for terrace.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Zona Velha do Funchal, CC BY-SA 4.0 via Wikimedia
items.must_order: Hot stone beef/tuna, bolo de mel

items.name: Brasa Viva
items.tip: Family-friendly in Sao Vicente. Tender, juicy, traditionally prepared espetada. Near Venda Nova poncha tavern.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Fontes do Horacio
items.tip: Hidden gem in Estreito da Calheta. Among the best espetada on the island. Feels like someone's home. Features Bella the robot server.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante Beira Mar
items.tip: Restaurant of choice for locals at Calheta marina. Polvo, grilled limpets, fish stew, homemade sangria. Relaxed vibe.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Leme Marisqueira
items.tip: Right on Calheta marina with ocean views. Varied seafood menu, Portuguese and Mediterranean dishes. Good wine selection.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante O Farolim
items.tip: Stunning Atlantic views in Calheta. Specializes in grilled seafood. Limpets, tuna steaks, scabbardfish with banana.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: O Forno
items.tip: Garlic prawns, beef espetada. Massive portions, tiny prices. Packed with locals weekends. Free ginja cherry liqueur.
items.image_credit: Espetada, Sirujs Enobs, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante Mercado Velho
items.tip: Charming traditional Portuguese in Machico. Mussels, shrimp and sauce, cod. Beloved by locals and tourists alike.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Espetada, CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia

items.name: A Pipa
items.tip: Porto da Cruz culinary gem. Best poncha on north coast. Tuna, limpets, sardines. Arrive noon. Closed Mon/Tue. No reservations.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Restaurante Praca do Engenho
items.tip: Beautiful sea and mountain views in Porto da Cruz. Salads, fish dishes. Great for day trips.
items.image_credit: Lapas grelhadas, Adriao, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Sabores do Curral
items.tip: Chestnut specialty dishes in Valley of the Nuns. Roof terrace with incredible valley views. Vegetarian options.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons
items.must_order: Chestnut soup, pork loin with chestnuts

items.name: Abrigo do Pastor
items.tip: Former shepherd shelter. Wild boar, stewed goat, roasted suckling pig, T-bone. Rustic decor preserves original charm.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Lapas grelhadas, CC BY-SA 2.5 via Wikimedia
items.must_order: Wild boar, espetada de vaca com osso

items.name: Las Caraibas
items.tip: Limited menu focused on quality execution in Seixal. Bacalhau Verde, gambas soup served in a bread loaf.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran cuisine, Zona Velha do Funchal, CC BY-SA 4.0 via Wikimedia
items.must_order: Bacalhau Verde, gambas soup in bread loaf

items.name: Talho do Canico
items.tip: Butcher shop + communal grill. Choose meat, season it, grill over open flames. Standing only. Thu-Sat ONLY. Locals-only vibe.
items.image_credit: Zona Velha, Funchal, PESP/Wikimedia (DarwIn), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Mercado dos Lavradores
items.tip: Go to upper floor for local prices. Avoid ground-floor fruit hustlers. Fish market best early AM. Art Deco architecture (1940).
items.image_credit: Photo by Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Santo da Serra Sunday Market
items.tip: Local produce vendors, street food stalls with local cider and wine. Barraca d'Avo bar serves excellent poncha.

items.name: Rei da Poncha
items.tip: 'The King of Poncha.' Try a meter of ponchas -- multiple mini glasses to sample all flavors. Popular with locals and visitors.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Venda Velha
items.tip: Probably the best poncha in Funchal. Weekend DJs, vintage decor. Lively party atmosphere.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: A Mercadora
items.tip: Traditional poncha experience in central Funchal. Easy to find.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Pharmacia do Bento
items.tip: Central downtown Funchal location. Easy access for poncha stop.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Os Castrinhos
items.tip: Funchal outskirts. More local atmosphere away from tourist center. Also serves carne de vinha d'alhos.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Madeira Rum House
items.tip: Massive rum collection. All poncha flavors. Not a tourist trap -- locals drink here. Lemon = connoisseur's choice.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Taberna da Poncha
items.tip: THE island institution. Serra d'Agua. EUR 3/glass. Peanut shells on floor, business cards on walls. Pilgrimage-worthy.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Bar Filhos D'Anjos
items.tip: Birthplace of poncha in Camara de Lobos. Rustic interiors, CR7 photos. Authentic experience.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Bar Number Two
items.tip: Terrace with views of Camara de Lobos bay. Laid-back, friendly. Great for chatting with locals.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Engenhos do Norte
items.tip: At the Porto da Cruz rum distillery. Northern coast poncha tradition. Tour distillery and taste rums.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: A Venda do Andre
items.tip: Quinta Grande, hills above Cabo Girao. Open since 1950s. Was half poncha bar, half grocery. Feels like a museum.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Bar do Luis
items.tip: Faial location. Perfect post-hike poncha stop after Eagle's Rock hike.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Cabo Aereo Cafe
items.tip: Sao Jorge north coast. Good poncha stop after north coast trail hikes.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Sr. Joao
items.tip: Ponta do Sol. Near Levada Nova trail. Post-hike poncha in warm microclimate.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Snack Bar Boca da Encumeada
items.tip: Mountain location at Encumeada pass. Post-hike refreshment at altitude.
items.image_credit: Representative: Poncha, Mitsjol, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Fabrica Santo Antonio
items.tip: Oldest confectionery in Madeira (1893). 5th generation. Bolo de mel, sugar cane biscuits, fennel candy. A living museum.
items.image_credit: Bolo de mel, Tim Walker, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Padaria Pastelaria Mariazinha
items.tip: Where locals start mornings. Excellent pasteis de nata, bolo de mel. 2 nata + 1 croissant + 1 spinach pocket = EUR 5.
items.image_credit: Pastel de nata, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Petit Fours Patisserie
items.tip: THE best pasteis de nata on the island according to TripAdvisor. Freshly baked breads, light lunch options.
items.image_credit: Pastel de nata, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Opan Bakery
items.tip: Ubiquitous chain, always excellent. Pastel de nata, salami cake (chocolate), pizza slices. Budget lunch offers. Avenida Arriaga branch recommended.
items.image_credit: Pastel de nata, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: A Confeitaria
items.tip: Rated #1 bakery in Funchal on TripAdvisor. Always busy with locals. Sandwiches, wraps, cakes. Rua dos Aranhas branch best.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran bakery, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Rodripan Bakery
items.tip: Near Porto Moniz. Pasteis de nata, bolo de arroz, pineapple pastries. Perfect fuel stop on north coast drives. Visit early.
items.image_credit: Pastel de nata, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: UauCacau
items.tip: Artisan chocolates: maracuja, poncha, Madeira wine, salted caramel flavors. Exceptional quality. Hot chocolate.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran bakery, Ana Cake Design, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Mya Petit Cafe
items.tip: Instagram-friendly pink interior. Avocado toast, Buddha bowls, pancakes. Excellent brunch spot.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran bakery, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Cafe Fortaleza
items.tip: Behind Sao Joao do Pico Fortress. Artisan lollies (passion fruit especially), local craft beer. Great atmosphere.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran bakery, Tim Walker, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: O Giro
items.tip: Freshly made churros with ice cream (Kinder Bueno flavor). EUR 3.50 generous portion. Thin, crispy, piping hot.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran bakery, Ana Cake Design, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Loja do Cha
items.tip: Proper English tea behind the cathedral. Extensive tea menu, cakes, crepes. The square is a sun trap year-round.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeiran bakery, SergioPT, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Blandy's Wine Lodge
items.tip: 7 generations. Tours from premium (2 wines) to private (5 wines). Vineyard tour at Quinta de Santa Luzia is excellent.
items.image_credit: Photo by H. Zell, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Pereira d'Oliveira
items.tip: FREE tastings with traditional cakes! 1.5M litres of old vintage stock. Connoisseur's choice. No booking needed. Since 1850.
items.image_credit: D'Oliveiras tasting hall, Volodymyr Vlasenko, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: H.M. Borges
items.tip: Founded 1877. Silver Experience: 40-min cellar tour + 2 wine tasting. Artwork by Max Romer. Mon-Fri 9am-1pm, 2:30-5:30pm.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeira wine, Richard Gray, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Vinhos Barbeito
items.tip: 'The Lafite of Madeira.' Family-run since 1946. Farm setting in Camara de Lobos. Platinum tour: 90min, 8 tastings, EUR 24.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeira wine, Volodymyr Vlasenko, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Quinta do Barbusano
items.tip: Sao Vicente. 6 wines, floor-to-ceiling valley views. Vineyard tour with petiscos (snacks). Combines wine with north coast excursion.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeira wine, Richard Gray, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Terras do Avo
items.tip: Near Sao Vicente. Lovely tasting rooms with amazing views. Edges out Quinta do Barbusano on wine quality per reviewers.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeira wine, Volodymyr Vlasenko, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Engenhos do Norte Distillery
items.tip: Porto da Cruz rum distillery. Tour and taste sugarcane rum (aguardente de cana) -- the base of poncha. Gift shop sells bolo de mel.
items.image_credit: Representative: Madeira wine, Richard Gray, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Camara de Lobos
items.tip: Churchill's fishing village. Colorful boats, great poncha bars. Start point for espetada restaurants in Estreito.
items.image_credit: Photo by Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Curral das Freiras
items.tip: Valley of the Nuns. Try chestnut cake and ginja at Sabores do Curral (terrace with valley views). 25 min drive from Funchal. Hike down from Eira do Serrado viewpoint (1h10m). Nov 1 Chestnut Festival.
items.image_credit: Photo by Anne and David from Kent, England UK, Public Domain, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Machico
items.tip: Pleasant town with imported golden sand beach. O Forno restaurant (garlic prawns, free ginja). Near airport.
items.image_credit: Donarreiskoffer, CC BY 3.0, Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Santana
items.tip: Traditional A-frame thatched houses. Quick photo stop. Base for PR9 Queimadas hikes.
items.image_credit: Photo by Ximonic (Simo Räsänen), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Porto da Cruz
items.tip: Hidden gem. Seawater pool, Engenho do Norte rum distillery, best surf. A Pipa = best poncha (closed Sun/Mon).

items.name: Sao Vicente
items.tip: Quiet town with great promenade. Quebramar restaurant (rotating floor). Caves nearby.

items.name: Calheta
items.tip: Golden sand beach (imported from Morocco). Warmest microclimate. Saccharum hotel sunset rooftop.
items.image_credit: Photo by Asurnipal, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Ponta do Sol
items.tip: Warm microclimate. Digital nomad hub. Harbor viewpoint for sunset. Sr. Joao poncha bar nearby.

items.name: Jardim do Mar Village
items.tip: Car-free 'Garden of the Sea' village. Subtropical flowers, narrow streets, surf spot. Not a formal garden.

items.name: Paul do Mar
items.tip: Isolated fishing village at cliff base. Precipicio viewpoint above for sunset.

items.name: Fanal Forest
items.tip: UNESCO laurel forest. Ancient 600-year-old twisted trees in fog. Tim Burton vibes. Best early AM or post-rain.

items.name: Calhau da Lapa
items.tip: Fishermen's caves in volcanic cliffs. 700 steep stairs or boat. Waterfall, clear water. You must climb back up!

items.name: Achadas da Cruz Cable Car
items.tip: Europe's steepest cable car (98% slope). EUR 3 return, CASH ONLY. 8am-7pm. Most tourists skip this. Incredible views.
items.image_credit: Photo by Hansueli Krapf, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Pico Ruivo
items.tip: 1862m -- highest point in Madeira. Reach via PR1.2 from Achada do Teixeira (2.5-3h round trip). 360-degree views.
items.image_credit: Photo by Diego Delso, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Ribeiro Frio
items.tip: PR11 Balcoes + PR10 start. Free trout farm. Victor's Snack Bar for poncha. Bus 56 from Funchal.

items.name: Parque Florestal das Queimadas
items.tip: PR9 Caldeirao Verde start. Limited parking -- arrive before 8:30am. Picnic area, restrooms, thatched-roof building.

items.name: Zona Velha
items.tip: Heart of nightlife. Painted doors on Rua de Santa Maria. Bar-hop between Rei da Poncha, Venda Velha, Trap Music Bar.
items.image_credit: Photo by PESP/Wikimedia, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Vereda do Larano
items.tip: THE most underrated hike in Madeira (Reddit consensus). Coastal cliffs, 300m drops, carved-into-cliff path. Machico to Porto da Cruz. FREE, no reservation needed.
items.image_credit: Paulo SP / DarwIn, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR3.1 - Caminho Real do Monte
items.tip: Historic cobblestone 'Royal Road' from Funchal to Monte. Passes Pico Alto viewpoint (1129m) and an old 1784 canal. Starts at Funchal Ecological Park.
items.image_credit: Luis Miguel Bugallo Sanchez, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR5 - Vereda das Funduras
items.tip: Starts at Portela viewpoint with views of Porto da Cruz and Penha d'Aguia. Descends through Laurissilva forest. Less crowded than PR8 for east-side exploration.
items.image_credit: Ondrej Zvacek, CC BY 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR12 - Caminho Real da Encumeada
items.tip: Historic 'Royal Road' from Boca da Corrida to Encumeada. Views of Curral das Freiras and both north/south valleys. PARTIALLY CLOSED to km 3.5 as of Jan 2026. Popular Pico Grande detour.
items.image_credit: Gerda Arendt, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR14 - Levada dos Cedros
items.tip: One of Madeira's oldest levadas (17th century). Deep UNESCO Laurissilva forest with 30-40m tall trees. Starts near Fanal. Combines well with PR13.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR20 - Vereda do Jardim do Mar
items.tip: Short descent from Prazeres through agricultural terraces to coastal Jardim do Mar. Ocean views. CLOSED indefinitely.
items.image_credit: Dreizung, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR23 - Levada da Azenha
items.tip: Ultra-short agricultural levada near Gaula. Flat, shaded forest trail. Great for beginners or a quick evening stroll. Suitable for all ages.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.2/6.3 - Lagoa do Vento
items.tip: The BIGGER waterfall near Rabaçal. Shorter and quieter than PR6, but BIGGER waterfall. Via Levada do Alecrim to Lagoa do Vento lagoon. Last 900m steep and slippery. Tour groups never make it here. WARNING: abyss sections, no protection.
items.image_credit: OlDie1966, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Caldeirão do Inferno Extension
items.tip: Extension beyond PR9 Caldeirão Verde to a second dramatic waterfall amphitheater. Total round trip from Queimadas: ~17.4km. Same trailhead as PR9. Very long day (9-10h). 11 tunnels. Only for fit hikers with an early start.
items.image_credit: VillageHero, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Levada Nova & Levada do Moinho
items.tip: HIGHEST-RATED trail on AllTrails (4.7 stars, 4752 reviews). Circular levada loop near Ponta do Sol through valleys and traditional terraced farmland. Passes old watermill ruins. One tunnel. TEMPORARILY CLOSED — check status.
items.image_credit: Sarang, Public Domain, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Pico Grande (via PR12)
items.tip: Hidden gem between Madeira's two celebrity peaks. Out-and-back from Boca da Corrida, branches off PR12 to dramatic volcanic spire summit. Best alternative while PR1 is closed. 1051 AllTrails reviews.
items.image_credit: Gerda Arendt, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.4 - Levada Velha do Rabaçal
items.tip: Quieter Rabaçal alternative. Follows one of Madeira's oldest levadas through dense Laurissilva forest. Includes the 1855 Tunel das Estrebarias — first tunnel to bring north coast water south. Peaceful, uncrowded.
items.image_credit: Bjorn Christian Torrissen, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR1.1 - Vereda da Ilha
items.tip: Traverses from Pico Ruivo shelter through two Natura 2000 ecosystems. Steep descent through laurel forest to Ilha village. Less crowded than PR1.
items.image_credit: Luis Miguel Bugallo Sanchez, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR1.3 - Vereda da Encumeada
items.tip: Ridge walk from Pico Ruivo westward to Encumeada pass. Crosses laurel forest and volcanic escarpment. Currently closed due to 2024 fire damage.
items.image_credit: Gerda Arendt, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR2 - Vereda do Urzal
items.tip: Epic south-to-north coast crossing. Climbs from Curral das Freiras through indigenous laurel forest to Boaventura. One of the island's great traverse routes.
items.image_credit: Ximonic (Simo Rasanen), CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR3 - Vereda do Burro
items.tip: CLOSED (Aug 2024 fire damage). Descent from Pico do Areeiro to Funchal Ecological Park. Passes Poco da Neve (1813 snow reservoir). When open: great alternative to PR1 for high mountain experience.
items.image_credit: Luis Miguel Bugallo Sanchez, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR4 - Levada do Barreiro
items.tip: Connects Poco da Neve to Funchal Ecological Park. Family-friendly with panoramic views over Funchal. Currently partially open.
items.image_credit: Luis Miguel Bugallo Sanchez, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.5 - Vereda do Pico Fernandes
items.tip: Quiet backdoor route to Rabacal valley from Paul da Serra. 360-degree panorama from Pico Fernandes at 1,400m. Less crowded approach to 25 Fontes.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.6 - Vereda do Tunel do Cavalo
items.tip: Unique trail featuring an 800m tunnel built 1863-1877. Requires flashlight and waterproof shoes. Hidden gem alternative approach to 25 Fontes.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.7 - Camara de Carga do Rabacal
items.tip: Short but steep descent along water channel to a nearly 1km tunnel into Rabacal. Can combine with PR28, PR13, PR6 for 25km mega-loop.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR6.8 - Levada do Paul II (Accessible Trail)
items.tip: Madeira's wheelchair-accessible trail on Paul da Serra plateau. Wide smooth surface, suitable for strollers. Follows levada through flowering gorse. Almost never crowded.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR9.1 - Caldeirao Verde (Accessible Trail)
items.tip: Accessible variant of the Caldeirao Verde levada. Wheelchair and stroller friendly. Peaceful forested walk without the tunnels and exposure of full PR9.
items.image_credit: VillageHero, CC BY-SA 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR13.1 - Vereda da Palha Carga
items.tip: The quiet backdoor route to 25 Fontes waterfall. Descends old firewood-carrying path through laurissilva. Far less crowded than main PR6 approach. A genuine hidden gem.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR15 - Vereda da Ribeira da Janela
items.tip: Old footpath from Fanal to Ribeira da Janela. Descends through forest to agricultural terraces, vineyards, and Madeira's longest watercourse.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR16 - Levada Faja do Rodrigues
items.tip: Lush forest path to multiple waterfalls with tunnel passages leading to an epic canyon. One of the most spectacular levada walks. Currently closed.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR19 - Caminho Real do Paul do Mar
items.tip: Historic royal road from Prazeres down 534m to the fishing village of Paul do Mar. Stone-paved steps, agricultural terraces. Ends at waterfront bars. Short but steep.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR21 - Caminho do Norte
items.tip: Historic trading route between south and north villages. Traverses UNESCO laurissilva forest. Ends at Ribeira Grande, known for traditional wicker basket weaving.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR22 - Vereda do Chao dos Louros
items.tip: Short circular loop through Natura 2000 laurissilva forest. Natural viewpoint over Sao Vicente valley. Quick add-on for hikers at Encumeada.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR27 - Glaciar de Planalto
items.tip: Unique geological trail showing glaciation evidence from ~25,000 years ago. U-shaped glacial valley, eroded cinder cone, moraine deposits. Only geological tourism trail on Madeira. Currently closed.
items.image_credit: Luis Miguel Bugallo Sanchez, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: PR28 - Levada da Rocha Vermelha
items.tip: Adventurous trail from Fanal with a 1.6km dark tunnel, waterfalls, and epic views of Rabacal valley. Can combine with PR13 for mega-loop. Currently closed.
items.image_credit: Dietmar Rabich, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

items.name: Calhau da Lapa
items.tip: 700 steps down to a waterfall, swimming spot, and colorful fishermen's cave-houses inside volcanic cliffs. One of Madeira's best-kept secrets. Bring water and good shoes.

items.name: Cascata dos Anjos
items.tip: Waterfall that pours directly over the coastal road ER 101. Drive through it or stop and walk under. Unique photo opportunity. Best after rain.

items.name: Engenhos do Norte Rum Distillery
items.tip: Only steam-powered rum distillery in Europe. Vintage 1920s equipment still in use. Free tours during sugarcane season (Mar-Apr). Try the aged agricole rum. In Porto da Cruz.

items.name: Savoy Palace
items.tip: Largest spa in Portugal (3,000 sqm), two rooftop infinity pools, 5 restaurants. Modern dramatic architecture with tropical plants integrated into glass and concrete.

items.name: Reid's Palace, A Belmond Hotel, Madeira
items.tip: Iconic cliff-top hotel since 1891 where Churchill painted. Michelin-starred William Restaurant, famous afternoon tea, and pool carved into the cliff face.

items.name: The Cliff Bay (Porto Bay)
items.tip: Direct ocean access with saltwater swimming platform, home to Il Gallo d'Oro (2 Michelin stars). Serene garden atmosphere with panoramic sea views.

items.name: Quinta da Casa Branca
items.tip: Member of Small Luxury Hotels of the World. Set on a historic wine estate with 28,000 sqm of subtropical gardens and a banana plantation. Anti-resort elegance.

items.name: Quinta Jardins do Lago
items.tip: Ranked #1 hotel in Funchal on TripAdvisor. Magnificent gardens with heated pool, bridge feature, and immaculate rooms with garden or sea views. Intimate and refined.

items.name: Quinta da Bela Vista
items.tip: 5-star boutique manor house with tranquil gardens, traditional decor, and serene hilltop atmosphere. Known for warm attentive service and spa with sauna.

items.name: Pestana Casino Park
items.tip: Oscar Niemeyer-designed 5-star on 15,000 sqm of gardens adjacent to Funchal Casino. Dramatic brutalist architecture, ocean views, and resort-scale facilities.

items.name: Meliá Madeira Mare
items.tip: 5-star in the Lido zone with 220 rooms, most with ocean-view balconies. Infinity pool, spa, and direct access to the seafront promenade.

items.name: Enotel Lido
items.tip: 5-star all-inclusive overlooking the Atlantic with indoor/outdoor pools, spa, sauna, and direct promenade access. One of few genuine all-inclusive options on Madeira.

items.name: Vidamar Resort Hotel Madeira
items.tip: Oceanfront 5-star with direct Atlantic access in the Lido area. Multiple pools, large spa, and panoramic ocean views from most rooms. Great for families.

items.name: Castanheiro Boutique Hotel
items.tip: Best value in central Funchal. Rooftop lap pool with harbour views, organic seaweed spa, and walking distance to everything. Exceptional staff consistently praised.

items.name: The Vine Hotel
items.tip: Award-winning design hotel with wine theme. Rooftop infinity pool, UVA restaurant (French-Madeiran fusion), and Wine Therapy Spa. Minimalist modern aesthetic.

items.name: ARTS IN Hotel Conde Carvalhal
items.tip: Charming boutique hotel in a historic building with magnificent gardens and 10,000 sqm grounds. Heated outdoor pool, spacious rooms with garden views, family-run warmth.

items.name: Sé Boutique Hotel
items.tip: Old-world European charm meets modern boutique. Rooftop bar with city views, quirky retro atmosphere, and central location steps from the Cathedral.

items.name: TURIM Santa Maria Hotel
items.tip: Modern 4-star in the heart of Old Town with rooftop pool and restaurant. 92 rooms with magnificent views, walking distance to painted doors street and harbour.

items.name: Hotel Madeira
items.tip: Well-known 3-star with personalized service in Old Town. Excellent location near Mercado dos Lavradores, friendly staff, and good breakfast. Solid mid-range pick.

items.name: Hotel do Carmo (The Editory Garden Carmo)
items.tip: Stylish mid-century modern property with rooftop pool and panoramic ocean views. 5-minute walk to farmers market. Free breakfast included. Great value.

items.name: Porto Santa Maria (PortoBay)
items.tip: Adults-only waterfront hotel in Old Town with kitchenettes in all rooms. 30+ restaurants within 3-minute walk. Best restaurant-access location in Funchal.

items.name: Porto Mare (PortoBay)
items.tip: All-in-one resort with 5 pools, 4 restaurants, spa, and sports facilities. Free shuttle to Funchal center. Great for families wanting resort-style amenities.

items.name: The Views Baía (Adults Only)
items.tip: Adults-only 4-star with full-service spa, indoor and outdoor pools, and 2 restaurants. Scenic beauty with excellent amenities and top-notch service.

items.name: Hotel Baía Azul
items.tip: Newly renovated 4-star, 4-minute walk from beachfront. Consistently praised for staff, excellent breakfasts, and spectacular sea views. Excellent value.

items.name: Pestana CR7 Funchal
items.tip: Cristiano Ronaldo collaboration with Pestana Group. Contemporary lifestyle hotel 300m from marina with rooftop pool. Modern design, harbour views, great for sports fans.

items.name: Hotel Girassol - Suite Hotel
items.tip: 4-star suite hotel with separate living areas in most rooms. Seafront location, pool with bar, expansive breakfast, and spa. Good space for the price.

items.name: Madeira Panoramico Hotel
items.tip: Hillside 4-star with stunning panoramic views of Funchal bay and mountains. Two pools, tennis, squash, and free shuttle service. Great value with a view.

items.name: Quinta do Monte Panoramic Gardens
items.tip: Historic manor house in Monte village surrounded by mature gardens. 2-minute walk to cable car terminal, indoor pool, and Monte Garden restaurant. Best value hillside stay.

items.name: Quinta Mirabela
items.tip: Intimate boutique hotel with breathtaking views of Funchal and the ocean. Tranquil hillside setting with tasteful public spaces and personable service.

items.name: Pestana Village Garden Hotel
items.tip: 4-star garden resort with traditional Madeiran architecture spread across 5,000 sqm of tropical gardens. Fitness facilities, pool, and quiet residential setting.

items.name: Pestana Promenade
items.tip: Modern 4-star on the oceanfront promenade. Contemporary design, ocean-view rooms, rooftop pool, and direct access to Lido seafront walking path.

items.name: Pestana Churchill Bay
items.tip: 4-star boutique in the fishing village Churchill loved to paint. Panoramic harbour views, modern design blending with historic setting, and rooftop pool.

items.name: Pestana Fisherman Village
items.tip: Stylish boutique in the historic fishing harbour surrounded by banana plantation hillsides. Rooftop panoramic pool, excellent breakfast, and tasteful rustic-modern design.

items.name: Estalagem da Ponta do Sol
items.tip: Design hotel on a cliff edge above the village, renovated from a 19th-century quinta. 54 rooms with ocean/cliff/village views, outdoor and indoor pools, and the digital nomad hub town at your feet.

items.name: Escarpa - The Madeira Hideaway
items.tip: Exclusive hideaway perched atop a dramatic escarpment with infinity pool and hot tub overlooking the Atlantic. Rooms and apartments available. Tranquility and natural beauty.

items.name: Saccharum Resort & Spa (Savoy Signature)
items.tip: 5-star design resort on the southwest coast next to Madeira's only sandy beach. Rooftop infinity pool, premium spa, and spectacular west-facing sunset views from the Fly bar.

items.name: Calheta Beach Hotel (Savoy Signature)
items.tip: One of few all-inclusive options in Madeira, directly on Calheta's golden sand beach. 153 rooms with balconies, 3 restaurants, beach bar, and marina views.

items.name: Hotel Atrio
items.tip: Family-run boutique hotel above Calheta with 22 rooms, 10,000 sqm garden, and heated pool. Levada trail starts at the property. Peaceful hillside retreat with mountain views.

items.name: Aqua Natura Bay
items.tip: 4-star right beside Porto Moniz's famous natural lava pools (free guest access year-round). Modern rooms with Atlantic views, hot tub, and friendly service. Best north coast base.

items.name: Aqua Natura Madeira Hotel
items.tip: Elegant 4-star perched on the rugged northwest coast with Atlantic Ocean views. Sister property to Aqua Natura Bay with its own restaurant and coastal atmosphere.

items.name: Hotel Euro Moniz
items.tip: Affordable 3-star near the natural pools with indoor pool, restaurant, and bar. Good budget base for exploring Porto Moniz and the northwest coast.

items.name: Quinta do Furão
items.tip: Spectacular cliffside hotel on 5 acres of organic gardens with dramatic north-coast views. Pool, sauna, and direct access to levada trails. Best-rated property in Santana.

items.name: Hotel O Colmo
items.tip: Central Santana location near traditional thatched houses. 50 rooms, heated pool, jacuzzi, and restaurant. Friendly staff and convenient for north coast exploration.

items.name: Dreams Madeira Resort Spa & Marina
items.tip: Part of Hyatt's World of Dreams. Clifftop resort with marina, spa, multiple pools, and panoramic views of Desertas Islands. Secluded east coast location near Ponta de São Lourenço.

items.name: Dom Pedro Madeira
items.tip: 4-star in Machico bay with panoramic sea views and Desertas Islands vistas. Near sandy beach, 10 minutes from airport. Live music and waterfront dining.

items.name: Albatroz Beach & Yacht Club
items.tip: 5-star beachfront near the airport with yacht club facilities, pools, and spa. Couples rate it 9.4. Excellent base for east coast exploration and Ponta de São Lourenço.

items.name: Estalagem do Vale
items.tip: Historic country-house inn in the Laurissilva Forest valley (UNESCO World Heritage). Indoor/outdoor pools, restaurant with €20 set dinner menu. Genuine nature retreat.

items.name: Estalagem do Mar
items.tip: 99-room hotel in the centre of São Vicente with 2 outdoor pools, tennis court, sauna, and restaurant. Close to volcanic caves. Good mid-range north coast option.

items.name: Casa da Piedade
items.tip: Charming guesthouse on the spectacular north coast with Wi-Fi and warm hospitality. Consistently praised as 'the best' by guests. Walking distance to São Vicente centre and volcanic caves.

items.name: North Coast Guest House (Madeira Surf Lodge)
items.tip: Recently renovated 8-room guesthouse 1km from centre with mountain views, garden, free WiFi and parking. Budget-friendly surf-oriented base on the north coast.

items.name: Jaca Hostel
items.tip: Best-rated hostel in Funchal, housed in a 19th-century family home. Garden, bar, inner yard, and 1-minute walk to city hall. Cozy vibe with excellent social atmosphere.

items.name: 29 Madeira Hostel
items.tip: Clean and comfortable hostel in central Funchal with exceptional staff. Dorms and private rooms available. Walking distance to all major attractions and transport.

items.name: Santa Maria Hostel
items.tip: Renovated historic building in Old Town retaining original Madeiran box roofs and wood beams. Close to beach, painted doors, and all city sights. Social atmosphere.

items.name: Casa do Papagaio Verde
items.tip: Affordable guesthouse on Funchal outskirts with sea views, beautiful garden, homemade jam breakfast, and some rooms with cooking facilities. Warm, welcoming owners.

items.name: A Casa Do Caseiro
items.tip: 8 rooms with private balconies and panoramic Funchal Bay views. Swimming pool, snack bar, and peaceful residential setting in Santa Luzia, 1.6 miles from centre.

items.name: Dazkarizeh73
items.tip: Exotic boutique hotel with outdoor infinity pool and hot tub with ocean views. Fitness centre, snack bar, and unique design aesthetic on the south coast between Funchal and Calheta.

items.name: Whale & Dolphin Watching
items.tip: Book morning tour (96% sighting rate). VipDolphins (EUR 65-95, luxury catamaran, max 17 pax) or Ventura (EUR 25-48, RIB) both excellent. Depart Pier 8, Marina do Funchal. March = dolphins + pilot whales guaranteed; orcas possible.

items.name: Carreiros do Monte (Toboggan Ride)
items.tip: Arrive before 10am to avoid 1-2 hour waits. Cash only, no online booking. Starts right outside Monte Palace Garden exit (natural combo). 2km downhill, ~10 min. Ends at Livramento (NOT Funchal center). EUR 35 for 2 people. Fun once but touristy.
